attributes.alt: Book cover for Water, Little Water by Jorge Tetl Argueta; illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcantara. The cover shows a deer drinking water from a pool. A big waterfall is in the background, along with tropical plants and trees.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Ask children to look at pictures of water and say if the water is a lake, a river, a cloud, rain, or dew.
Invite children to think of other places where they could find water and say what they know about it.
How can we care for our world?
What does that book tell you about Earth?
Pretend you are a scientist. What will you investigate?
Tell me what you know about water.
and decorate and color around it?
Draw a picture of an ocean. What colors will you use?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
What can you build that could be used to carry water?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Water, Little Water by Jorge Tetl Argueta; illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcantara. The cover shows a deer drinking water from a pool. A big waterfall is in the background, along with tropical plants and trees.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Talk about persisting at a task to reach a goal.
Ask children to look at pictures of people trying to do different things, and describe what they are trying to do.
How can we care for our world?
Can you show me a picture of water in the book?
Pretend you are taking pictures. Describe what you are taking pictures of.
What happens to water when it goes really cold?
Can you show me how to write the word
Draw a picture of some of the fun things you can do in water.
Can you think of a word that starts with the same letter as the word
Can you build something that you would see in the water?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Water, Little Water by Jorge Tetl Argueta; illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcantara. The cover shows a deer drinking water from a pool. A big waterfall is in the background, along with tropical plants and trees.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
What do we know about Little Water?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Use appropriate tone of voice.
Understand differences between living and non-living things.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Ask children to look at a picture, identify what they see in the picture, and then guess what the cognate is for that word.
Say a Spanish cognate and have children guess the matching English cognate.
How can we care for our world?
How did that book help you learn more about Earth?
Pretend you are a river. How would you move?
How can you measure how much water is in a container?
Write or draw how it feels to splash in cold water.
Can you show how water looks in the ocean?
What letters do you see around the classroom?
Build a tree with long roots. What materials will you use?

attributes.alt: The Big Chart of Big Ideas for You Can Help. The cover has a flower with a picture in each petal that shows a girl with her hand on a water faucet; a child handing a toy to another child; children recycling; a child growing plants; a child turning off a light switch, and a child driving a toy train.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: You Can Help

attributes.alt: Book cover for Water, Little Water by Jorge Tetl Argueta; illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcantara. The cover shows a deer drinking water from a pool. A big waterfall is in the background, along with tropical plants and trees.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about water and to introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question,
How can we care for our world?
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Guide children to look at pictures, identify the objects, and say if they should be recycled.
Invite children to talk about how they recycle at home.
How can we care for our world?
What do you like most about this book?
Pretend you are sorting cans and paper into separate containers.
Can you sort five objects from biggest to smallest?
Can you write a story about how water goes from the ocean to the sky?
Draw a picture of a river. What colors will you use?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
? What can you find in the room that also starts with that letter?
Use blocks to build a recycling bin.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Water, Little Water by Jorge Tetl Argueta; illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcantara. The cover shows a deer drinking water from a pool. A big waterfall is in the background, along with tropical plants and trees.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How does Little Water move from Earth to the sky?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement an imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt,
What would you do to take care of your neighborhood?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we care for our world?
What other books would you like to read about Earth?
Imagine you are Little Water climbing from deep in Earth to the surface.
Which body of water is bigger, a lake or an ocean?
Imagine a story about water that can talk. What would it say?
Can you draw a picture of Little Water’s journey?
Imagine a name for an ocean. What sound does it start with? What letter makes that sound?
Can you create something that can hold water?
